main event: On 6-25-57 in Wenatchee, Washington, a large light, ten times the size of Venus at its brightest, was observed for 7 minutes. The conclusion was that it was likely the star Arcturus, especially considering the observation was made through binoculars and yielded no further detail.
interesting points: The observation lasted for 7 minutes, allowing for a comprehensive study of the object.
The object was described as a strong white light moving from south to north, passing the horizon.
The observer used binoculars but could not distinguish any further features of the object.
The weather and winds aloft conditions at the time of the sighting were reported as perfect visibility and clear sky.
There was doubt expressed about the observation due to the observer's avid interest in science fiction, which was believed to influence their thinking.
sighted object: a large light, ten times the size of Venus at its brightest
witnesses: Engineer [Redacted] aged 48, residing in Wenatchee, Washington
